DOC.HEAD: Heating Oil Up Sharply Again; Gold, Silver Plunge
DOC.TEXT: Heating oil futures rose dramatically again Wednesday on the New York Mercantile Exchange as speculation continued that supplies would be tight amid continued cold weather. On other commodity markets, gold and silver prices plummeted as investment buying dried up; orange juice futures were widely mixed; livestock and meat were mixed; and grains and soybeans were mostly lower. With temperatures slowly warming, oil traders focused on reports of reduced production capacity at the Gulf of Mexico, where several refineries were forced to shut down because of cold-weather damage to equipment. The spot January heating-oil contract again led the gainers but analysts said the market could become extremely volatile in the next two sessions as the January contracts approach expiration on Friday. ``The risk-to-reward at these price levels dictates a lot of prudence and probably profit-taking,'' said William O'Neill, research director with Elders Futures Inc. in New York. Wholesale home heating oil settled .36 cent lower to 7.23 cent higher with January at 99.71 cents a gallon, a six-year high. In other energy futures, West Texas Intermediate crude oil finished .13 cent lower to .16 cent higher with February at $21.78 a barrel and unleaded gasoline was .09 cent lower to 2.45 cents higher with January at 60.85 cents a gallon. Gold futures settled $6 to $7 lower on New York's Commodity Exchange with the spot contract for delivery in December at $400.80 a troy ounce, a five-week low. Silver futures fell 27.2 cents to 30.8 cents with spot December settling at a seven-week low of $5.24 a troy ounce. Market analysts said the investment buying that drove precious metals up sharply in October and November had dwindled with the easing of international tensions. That development, compounded by typically thin holiday trading conditions, caused a dearth of willing buyers when commercial traders turned sellers early in Wednesday's session. ``There was nothing on the other side,'' said Stephen Platt, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago. ``As the market started breaking through chart support, you started seeing some computer-fund selling, which was not easily absorbed by speculators so the market pretty much got hammered.'' The recent bull move had carried spot gold to almost $420 an ounce and spot silver to nearly $5.90. Most orange juice futures soared the permitted daily limit of 5 cents a pound on the New York Cotton Exchange but the January contract fell 2.95 cents to $1.5015 a pound amid profit-taking after Tuesday's strong gains. Florida officials said they still could not estimate the damage from the weekend freeze in the orange groves, but an increasing number of experts said Brazilian imports and stockpiled Florida juice should prevent a sharp rise in cash prices. Cattle futures fell on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange amid profit-taking after steep gains on Tuesday. Hog futures rose and pork belly futures fell in light trading ahead of the Agriculture Department's monthly cold storage report. The report showed 68.7 million pounds of bellies in cold storage as of Dec. 1 compared with 39.8 million pounds a month earlier and 93.3 million pounds a year ago. Live cattle settled .15 cent to .48 cent lower with February at 77.45 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent to .43 cent lower with January at 84.82 cents a pound; hogs were .08 cent to .35 cent higher with February at 49.25 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .57 cent lower to .15 cent higher with February at 49.20 cents a pound. Grain and soybean futures prices ended mostly lower on the Chicago Board of Trade, led by a drop in the soybean market that analysts attributed mainly to technical factors.
